Heterogenized manganese catalyst for C-, and N-alkylation of ketones and amines with alcohols by pyrolysis of molecularly defined complexes Muhammad Sohail Ahmad Conceptualization Methodology Writing – original draft a b Yusuke Inomata Validation Investigation Writing – review & editing b c Tetsuya Kida Validation Writing – review & editing Supervision a c ⁎ a Institute of Industrial Nanomaterials, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan Institute of Industrial Nanomaterials Kumamoto University Kumamoto 860-8555 Japan aInstitute of Industrial Nanomaterials, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan b International Research Organization for Advanced Science and Technology (IROAST), Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan International Research Organization for Advanced Science and Technology (IROAST) Kumamoto University Kumamoto 860-8555 Japan bInternational Research Organization for Advanced Science and Technology (IROAST), Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan c Department of Applied Chemistry and Biochemistry, Graduate School of Science and Technology, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto, 860-8555, Japan Department of Applied Chemistry and Biochemistry Graduate School of Science and Technology Kumamoto University Kumamoto 860-8555 Japan cDepartment of Applied Chemistry and Biochemistry, Graduate School of Science and Technology, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto, 860-8555, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author at: Institute of Industrial Nanomaterials, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan. Institute of Industrial Nanomaterials Kumamoto University Kumamoto 860-8555 Japan Series of organic transformations are known to be catalyzed by molecularly well-defined homogeneous catalysts, however, it is difficult to recycle. Meanwhile, heterogeneous catalysts are required in many industrial processes due to their stability, and recyclability, but it is challenging to control on a molecular level. Herein, we set out the conversion of homogenous manganese complex into heterogeneous manganese-based catalyst via pyrolyzing the pre-formed crystalline polymer. The catalyst thus produced are then utilized for C–C/C–N bond-forming reactions, such as alkylation of ketones and/or amines, utilizing primary alcohols as an alkylating agent, under nearly mild conditions liberating water as the sole by-product. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Introduction Catalyst is immensely important for achieving more benign processes in the chemical, pharmaceutical, and materials industries [1]. However, most of the catalysts utilize transition and/or heavy metals as active sites. Due to the limited resources of these conventional metals catalysts, it is of substantial significance to find an alternative that could be more inexpensive and sustainable than the metals-dominated catalysts [2–5]. Recently, well-structured and crystallized nano-sized carbon materials have been extensively utilized in catalysis, because of their special electronic properties along with outstanding stability under harsh reaction conditions [4,6]. Specifically, the carbon matric might be functionalized to introduce heteroatoms (N, S, and B) containing defects [7,8], which is an ultimate coordination site for the single metal atoms [9,10]. Therefore, the nitrogen-carbon containing metals (Mn, Co, Fe, Ni, etc), utilizing nitrogen to anchor metal atoms, has attracted enormous attention as a representative linking the homogenous and heterogeneous catalysis [11], while the coordinated metal and nitrogen centers have revealed an excellent an in catalysis [12–15]. However, molecularly defined Manganese (Mn) coordination with nitrogen has been rarely reported for organic transformations [16,17]. Therefore, the development of molecularly defined Mn-based heterogeneous catalysts is immensely important to explore their sustainability in catalysis. The development of catalytic methods for the formation of C−C or C−N bonds plays an essential role in chemical synthesis [18]. Among various kinds of C−C and or C−N bond-forming reactions, the alkylation of ketones and or amines with alcohols still need noble metals (Au [19], Ru [20–22], Ir [23–30], Rh [26,31], Re [32], Os [33], and Pd [34–36]), or base metals (Ni, Mn, Cu, and Fe) [37–43] as catalysts. These metal catalysts dehydrogenate the alcohols to the corresponding carbonyl compound and then undergo condensation with carbonyl followed by hydrogenation reaction to furnish the corresponding products, called the “hydrogen auto-transfer or borrowing hydrogen process (BH)” (Scheme 1 ) [44–49]. Recently, remarkable progress in homogenous manganese complex catalyzed the hydrogen borrowing reactions have been made by various research groups including Elangovan et al. [50], Chakraborty et al. [51], Mastalir et al. [52], Fertig et al. [53], Bruneau-Voisine et al. [54], and many more (Scheme 2 ) [55]. However, a recyclable heterogeneous manganese-based catalyst for the hydrogen borrowing strategy remains elusive. Particularly, the alkylation reaction of ketone and/or amine by hydrogen borrowing strategy is very limited [56]. Herein, we report a protocol to prepare an Mn-based heterogeneous catalyst for the alkylation reactions of ketones, and/or amines with alcohols. Generally, the results revealed here constitute an example of heterogeneity of the complex, showing the perspective of this concept to replace very expensive and precious homogenous metals with low-cost carbon materials. Results and discussion The Mn-N-Graphene heterogeneous catalyst was synthesized by pyrolyzing a pre-formed crystal-like polymer based on manganese ethylene diamine (Supporting information). The chemical structure morphology of the Mn-N-Graphene catalyst was then measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The wide scan survey verifies the existence of C, O, N, and Cl in the catalyst surface (Fig. S1). The C 1s spectrum describes the dominant contribution of the four peaks with binding energies of 284.8, 285.8, 286.7, and 287.8 eV due to the C–C sp2, C–C sp3, C–O/C–N, and C=O or O=C–O types of carbon (Fig. 1(a)). The O 1s spectrum of the Mn-N-graphene (Fig. 1(b)) can be categorized into three peaks with binding energies of 533.7, 531.7, and 530.3 eV, which confirms the existence of C–O, C=O, and Mn=O, respectively. The N 1s XPS spectrum exhibits four N species, such as Mn–N at 399.2 eV, pyridinic N at 398.0 eV, pyrrolic type N at 400.7 eV, while graphitic at 401.5 eV (Fig. 1(c) [57,58]. The high-resolution Cl 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 1(d)) shows the peak at 197.7 eV corresponding to Mn–Cl species, and peaks at 199.6 eV (2p3/2) and 201.2 eV (2p1/2) due to the C–Cl. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) shows that the catalyst has a layered and sheet-like structure ((Figs. S3(a) and S4), respectively. In addition, Mn-based nanoparticles or nanoclusters are not observed by TEM. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectrum of the Mn-N-Graphene shows the formation of the graphitic carbon layer, which is in agreement with the TEM results, also the Mn diffractions were not observed (Fig. S6). Furthermore, a representative high-angle annular dark-field scanning) HADDF-STEM image (Fig. S3(b)) and the elemental mapping support the presence of C, N, O, and Mn (Fig. S3). In the Raman spectrum (Fig. S7), the G band around 1600 cm−1 further confirms the presence of graphitic carbon. In a preliminary catalyst screening, a series of catalysts such as complexes and other carbon-related materials were tested as a catalyst for the industrial benchmark of an alkylation reaction (Table 1 ). Initially, we choose acetophenone (1a) and benzyl alcohol (2a) as model substrates (Table 1), no product was detected when the reaction was carried out in toluene for 24 h at 125 °C in the absence of any catalyst (Entry 1). The alkylated product (3a) was formed in a trace amount when manganese oxide was used as a catalyst in the presence of tBuOK (Entry 2), also a low yield of the product was obtained when Mn-N-Graphene was utilized as a catalyst in the absence of tBuOK (Entry 3). Interestingly, 87% alkylated product was obtained, when 3 mol% of the tBuOK was added to the reaction mixture (Entry 4). Furthermore, employing carbon-based materials and Mn-EDA as catalysts were found much less active (Entries 5–7). When the reaction was carried out in the presence of other bases such as K2CO3, NaOH, or KOH, the alkylated product was achieved in much lower yields of 50, 59, and 65, respectively (Entries 8–10). Moreover, changing the nonpolar solvent, such as toluene, to the polar solvents e.g., DMSO, or tetrahydrofuran furnishes the desired product with a lower yield (Entries 11 and 12). Having the optimized conditions in hand (toluene, 125 °C, tBuOK 3 mol%, and Mn-N-Graphene), the scope of the manganese catalyzed C-alkylation of ketones with alcohols has been explored. As shown in Table 2 , the reaction of acetophenone bearing electron-donating substituents, including 4-methyl acetophenone and 4-methoxy acetophenone with benzyl alcohol produced substituted 1,3-diphenylpropan-1-one derivatives in excellent yield (Table 2, entries A–C). Under similar conditions, acetophenone bearing electron-withdrawing substituents at para position such as 4-chloroacetophenone and 4-bromo acetophenone also afforded selectively the corresponding C-alkylated products with good yields (Table 2, entries D and E). The halogen-substituted substrates were reported to show poor selectivity due to dehalogenation [59]. 4-methylbenzyl alcohol afforded excellent yield with substituted acetophenone bearing electron-donating functional groups (Table 2, entries F–H), while acetophenone having electron-withdrawing group shows moderate activity (Table 2, entries I and J). Furthermore, 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol shows a similar tendency (Table 2, entries K–O). benzyl alcohol with an electron-withdrawing substituent such as 4-trifluoromethylbenzyl alcohol with acetophenone derivatives produced selectively the corresponding alkylated products with good to moderate yields (Table 2, entries P-S). 1-hexanol as substrate afforded 66% of the target product (Table 2, entry T). The scope of the reaction was further probed by employing secondary alcohols, such as 1-phenyl ethanol (2b) (0.7 mmol) with 1a (0.5 mmol) and tBuOK (3 mol%) at 125 °C in the presence of Mn-N-Graphene, furnishing the corresponding alkylated ketone 4a in 68% (Scheme 3 ), previously it has been reported by homogenous Ru [60], and Ir [61], complexes. The C−N bond-forming reactions have a vital role in synthetic chemistry. As nitrogen-containing compounds have a wide scope in biological, pharmaceutical, drug delivery, and materials science [62]. Therefore, the development of a selective N-alkylation method that is cost-effective, salt-free, and environmentally benign is of considerable interest. In this regard, pioneering reports dealing with the N-alkylation of amines by alcohols utilizing homogenous catalysts were described individually by Zhao and Yan and co-workers [63,64]. Observing the good performance of the heterogeneous Mn-N-Graphene catalyst for the C-alkylation of ketone, we investigated the N-alkylation of amine with alcohol (Table 3 ). To demonstrate the usefulness of our heterogeneous catalytic system, an electron-withdrawing and donating a group of benzyl alcohol was examined under the optimized conditions producing the alkylated product in good yields (Table 3, entries 1–3). Recently, Subaramanian et al., reported that the manganese doped nitrogen graphene oxide was incompatible to catalyze the alkylation reaction of hexylamine substrate [56]. However, the reaction of 2a with hexylamine has been proceeded by Mn-N-Graphene, while giving the corresponding product in 43% yield (Table 3, entry 4). The main advantage of heterogeneous catalysis is the easy recovery and recyclability of the catalyst. The stability of the developed Mn-N-Graphene catalyst was then investigated (Fig. 2) and found that the catalyst didn't lose its catalytic activity even after five sequential cycles and afforded its original activity and offered the C-alkylated product 3a in excellent yield for the benchmark reaction (Fig. 2). Furthermore, based on recently reported mechanistic findings of Mn-catalyzed alkylation reaction ketones/amines [50,65–67], and our experimental investigations, we advise the plausible catalytic cycle (Scheme 4 ). Firstly, Mn-N-Graphene in the presence of base dehydrogenates the alcohol to aldehyde with the generation of H2 gas. Afterward, the condensation reaction of an aldehyde with ketone/amine occurs to form the intermediate chalcone/imine. Lastly, the transferred hydrogen of chalcone/imine intermediate utilizing H2 gas selectively generates the corresponding alkylated product (Scheme 4). Accordingly, the alkylation of ketone or amine using alcohols as an alkylating agent via borrowing hydrogenation utilizing heterogeneous Mn-N-Graphene catalyst has been accomplished. Conclusion In summary, we have developed a manganese-based heterogeneous catalyst for the efficient alkylation reaction of ketones/amines with alcohols as an alkylating agent, generating water, via a hydrogen transfer strategy. Moreover, the formation of the alkylated ketone was also achieved by the dehydrogenative coupling of a primary alcohol with secondary alcohol. Overall, this system might present an efficient, attractive strategy and could be a substitute for transition or precious metal-catalyzed systems for C–C/C–N bond-forming reactions. coredata.dc:description: Series of organic transformations are known to be catalyzed by molecularly well-defined homogeneous catalysts, however, it is difficult to recycle. Meanwhile, heterogeneous catalysts are required in many industrial processes due to their stability, and recyclability, but it is challenging to control on a molecular level. Herein, we set out the conversion of homogenous manganese complex into heterogeneous manganese-based catalyst via pyrolyzing the pre-formed crystalline polymer. The catalyst thus produced are then utilized for C–C/C–N bond-forming reactions, such as alkylation of ketones and/or amines, utilizing primary alcohols as an alkylating agent, under nearly mild conditions liberating water as the sole by-product.
coredata.dc:title: Heterogenized manganese catalyst for C-, and N-alkylation of ketones and amines with alcohols by pyrolysis of molecularly defined complexes
